titleStmt.title: A most joyfull declaration made by Colonell Skipon, sergeant maior generall of the whole army, to his regiment of officers and souldiers at their muster at Maiden-head Ian. 12 : wherein he doth most nobly declare his resolution to them all concerning his advancing forwards to the enemy, and to give them bataile with his single remenr of foote and his troope of horse and five peeces of ordnance : likewise a speech and protestation to these captains, namely Sergreant Major Francis, Captaine Man, Captaine Deacon, Captaine Tasker, Captaine Hawood, Captaine Harison : together with their answer to the same : likewise His Majesties message sent by Cap. Hearne and read in Guildhall on Fryday last, Ianuary 13, 1643.
titleStmt.author: Skippon, Philip, d. 1660.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A most joyfull declaration made by Colonell Skipon, sergeant maior generall of the whole army, to his regiment of officers and souldiers at their muster at Maiden-head Ian. 12 : wherein he doth most nobly declare his resolution to them all concerning his advancing forwards to the enemy, and to give them bataile with his single remenr of foote and his troope of horse and five peeces of ordnance : likewise a speech and protestation to these captains, namely Sergreant Major Francis, Captaine Man, Captaine Deacon, Captaine Tasker, Captaine Hawood, Captaine Harison : together with their answer to the same : likewise His Majesties message sent by Cap. Hearne and read in Guildhall on Fryday last, Ianuary 13, 1643.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the Harvard University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2011-07 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2011-08 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: A MOST JOYFÆ²LL DECLARATION Made by Colonell SKIPON Sergeant Maior Generall of the whole Army, to his Regiment of Officers and Souldiers, at their MuÅ¿ter at Maiden-head Ian. 12.

Wherein he doth moÅ¿t Nobly declare his ReÅ¿olution to them all, concerning his advancing forwards to the enemy, and to give them Bataile with his Single Rement of Foote, and his troope of HorÅ¿e, and Five Peeces of Ordnance.
LikewiÅ¿e a Speech and ProteÅ¿tation to theÅ¿e Captains, namely Sergeant Major Francis Captaine Man, Captaine Deacon, Captaine Tasker Captaine Hawood, Captaine HariÅ¿on.
Together with their AnÅ¿wer to the Å¿ame.
LikewiÅ¿e His MAJESTIES MeÅ¿Å¿age Å¿ent by Cap. Hearne and read in Guildhall on Fryday laÅ¿t Ianuary 13, 1643.

div.head: A moÅ¿t Joyfull DECLARATION Made by Colonell Skipon, Sergeant Maior Generall of the Army, January 12. at the generall MuÅ¿ter at Maiden-head.
div.p:
I Have Å¿ome PropoÅ¿itions that hath within theÅ¿e few hours uÅ¿ed from my breaÅ¿t, and having Å¿uch a faire oppertunity, at this time; J will God willing, declare
them unto you, which are as followeth.

MoÅ¿t Renowned, and undaunted Å¿pirits, J am Å¿o enjoyed to Å¿ee you all Å¿o heartable, in theÅ¿e Military affairs, and in the performance of your duty towards this cauÅ¿e, which you have now undertaken; That I am almoÅ¿t Å¿trucken into a Å¿ownd for joy, and indeed you have Å¿o won my heart, by theÅ¿e your valient actions, that I doe not value my life at the Å¿maleÅ¿t rate it can be valued at, but am willing to Å¿pend my deareÅ¿t blood, in this juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e, and amongÅ¿t you all.

Gentlemen, This which I have declared unto you by Gods helpe J will performe; And am willing to hazzard my Life for you all: But to declare my minde more fully unto you, J do deÅ¿ire of you, that you will obÅ¿erve
and obey theÅ¿e my InÅ¿tructions and advertiÅ¿ments to you all.
I. J doe exhort you, to Å¿erve GOD, and to doe your duty towards him; and in Å¿o doing it will be the greateÅ¿t meanes through Gods bleÅ¿sing, to make you all Conquerors, and MaÅ¿ters of the field.

II. J doe deÅ¿ire you, that you would offer no abuÅ¿e or wrong whatÅ¿oever, to any perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons where you are Quartered, or Billetted; and in Å¿o doing, you will bring honour, and fame upon your Å¿elves; And everlaÅ¿ting Glory and happineÅ¿Å¿e to your Soules.

III. J do here promiÅ¿e unto you, that this being performed by you, no duty
Å¿hall be wanting of my part, That doth belong to any perÅ¿on, honour, and the Military DiÅ¿cipline whatÅ¿oever: And as we do all now pray and deÅ¿ire for a Å¿eaÅ¿onable weather, Å¿o it is my hearty and earneÅ¿t deÅ¿ire, Å¿o Å¿oone as God be pleaÅ¿ed to give us Å¿uch a happy time, to advance toward our enemy, (which are now raiÅ¿ed for the after Ruine and deÅ¿truction of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion; For Gentlemen I muÅ¿t tell you, that your cauÅ¿e is Å¿o good, that God had never Å¿uch a worke in hand, Å¿ince the firÅ¿t Creation; And for the better encouragement of you all, J do proteÅ¿t and vow unto you, that as God hath beene pleaÅ¿ed to infect upon me this little Judgement which J have through my induÅ¿try obtained unto, in Forraigne Counties.

So am J fully ReÅ¿olved to declare it to you all, and to Å¿hew you what lies in my power, promiÅ¿eing in the
preÅ¿ence of him that knoweth the Å¿ecrets of all hearts, never to leave you Å¿o long as J have breath in my body and that Å¿o long as J have leggs to Å¿tand on, or hands to hold up my weapon againÅ¿t my enemy, I will doe my endeavoure for the defence and Å¿afeguard of you all, Thus gentlemen J have declared my mind to you J muÅ¿t now take my leave, and within theÅ¿e few dayes, J will be with you againe, where J am ReÅ¿olved to advance forwards.

This Å¿peech was Å¿poken January the 12. at the Generall MuÅ¿ter at maidenhead, where the Å¿ouldiers with loud acclamations cryed out, that they would loÅ¿e their lives with him, deÅ¿iring that they might fall on the enemy with all expedition.

div.head: HIS MAJESTIES MESSAGE Sent by Captaine Hearne, and reade in Guild-Hall on Fryday laÅ¿t, 1642.
div.p: THat His MajeÅ¿ty doth not entertaine any miÅ¿apprehenÅ¿ion of the love and loyalty of His City of London, but deÅ¿ires His good Subjects there, conÅ¿ider what confidence he can have of Å¿ecurity there, whileÅ¿t the Lawes of the Land are Å¿o notoriouÅ¿ly diÅ¿piÅ¿ed and trampled under foot, and Armes taken up againÅ¿t His conÅ¿ent, and expreÅ¿Å¿e command; and Alderman Pennington (Lord Maior) Cap. Ven, Foulk; and Manwaring, are there &c. And His MajeÅ¿ty would know, whether the Petitioners beleeve, that the reviling the Booke of common-prayer, and complying with, and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting perÅ¿ons who have attempted to kill His MajeÅ¿ty, be to defend His royall perÅ¿on and honour? And if they Å¿hall reforme other things diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing to His MaieÅ¿ty, and apprehend and committ to Å¿afe cuÅ¿tody, theÅ¿e foure men. His MaieÅ¿ty will Å¿peedily returne to them, and offers a generall pardon, &c. and as for His MaieÅ¿ties concurrence with the advice of His two HouÅ¿es of Parliament, His MaieÅ¿ty doubts not how farr beyond the example of His PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors, He hath concurred in paÅ¿sing Lawes, and uÅ¿ed all meanes to beget a right underÅ¿tanding betweene Him and them. And will therefore apply themÅ¿elves to thoÅ¿e, who by JuÅ¿t, Peaceable, and honourable PropoÅ¿itions to His MaieÅ¿ty, can onely beget that concurrence.
